title: Are illustrations or photos best for a children’s book? - Quora

response.answer_text: First, I’m answering on the assumption that by “children’s book” you mean a picture book for readers up to age 10. This being the case… There’s no single answer to this. My company’s children’s books are mostly illustrated, but one is all photography and another is a mix of photos and illustrations. Graphic and design choices should be driven by the story, the purpose of the book, and its intended readership. For example, our all-photo children’s book is about a real-life rescue dog who became a therapy dog, and the author happens to be the owner and a professional photographer. So she had tons of great photos of the dog in a variety of ways to support the story. There would be no reason at all to create illustrations, especially given that the book was about a real-life dog. The book with a mix of photos and illustrations is also a true story, but there weren’t many photos to show the story. So, we have illustrations for the “journey” part of the book and photos at the end to show the “heroic accomplishment.” Conversely, our other children’s books are fiction. To create fantastical, delightful, colorful, and expressive images through photography would be prohibitively difficult and expensive when an illustrator can do as well (if not better) for far less cost. So, the best advice I can offer is to think about the story. If it’s a real-life story, then photography *may* be the better choice; if it’s fiction, then illustrations are most likely the better choice. But no matter what, do what’s best visually. Even if I had a real-life story with many available photos, I wouldn’t use them if they weren’t great images. Thanks for the A2A! [Answered: Are illustrations or photos best for a children’s book?]

Children seem to have a stronger positive reaction to illustrations as opposed to photos. Take a look at what posters and artworks a child has in their bedroom. You are likely to see more illustrations that photos.
